issues.title: Can't jsonify list object
issues.body:
JSON standard (http://json.org/) say, that any entity can be object or array.
When I try:

```
jsonify(['a','b','c', 'd', 'e', 'f'])
```

I got an error:

```
ValueError: dictionary update sequence element #0 has length 8; 2 is required
```

I think it is not a correct answer from flask. It should returns a JSON-object with array.

comments_data.body:
This is a duplicate of #170. It's for security reasons as @mitsuhiko mentions. This is also documented. You can, however, make your own request, set the proper content-type header and use the json library to do this yourself if you're intent on by-passing it.

You could also do `jsonify({'objects': ['a', 'b', 'c',]})` if you wanted to.
you can also use the syntax `jsonify(results=['a', 'b', 'c'])`
Also if you'd like to read more about the security issues with returning Arrays in a json response: http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/security/
Thank you, guys.
If its intended, why isn't the error less cryptic?
:+1: on a more helpful error message
All pull requests are considered. The line you're most likely looking for is [in json.py](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/blob/master/flask/json.py#L237)
Also I would support the removal of this restriction, the attack vector was closed in ECMAScript 5 and doesn't affect any current browser.

@danielchatfield define "current". If you mean "most recently released version", then sure it's safe. If instead you mean "most widely used version" then you're likely wrong. I would expect this to affect a large number of IE users.
Latest version of IE that is vulnerable is IE 5.
Latest version of firefox that is vulnerable is 2.0.
Source: http://haacked.com/archive/2008/11/20/anatomy-of-a-subtle-json-vulnerability.aspx/

Given that it appears to be solved by browsers now it seems reasonable to allow lists now. 

I still feel somewhat uncomfortable with the idea though, considering it's a security issue.

How are other frameworks handling this?
It's also important to point out that this is easily worked around if you like to ignore the best practices of the framework you chose.

While that may be possible, if you have to defend the API with "it can be worked around" you have unquestionably failed at its design.

We should strive to be ahead and not behind when it comes to defining "the right way to do it".

I'm not sure if this was your intention but your comment moved me more in the let's allow lists position.

If we do go ahead with this, we may want to consider officially defining which browsers we support. Having a clear definition would help in finding a solution for this issue and others like it, which will inevitably be raised.

> I'm not sure if this was your intention but your comment moved me more in the let's allow lists position.

We'll never know ;)
I'm for allowing lists. Maybe we could mostly eliminate the security concerns by disallowing lists based on UA sniffing. It'd cause errors in production, but at least no security issues.

I'm not in support of UA sniffing.

Lets be realistic about this, I don't know how many people still use IE 5
but we are talking minuscule amounts of people here. This in itself makes
the attack not really feasible as it requires a user visiting an "evil
site" which is targeting a specific website that the victim has to be
logged into and using IE 5. An attacker would be waiting a pretty long time
(indefinitely) for someone like that to come along.

In any case, IE 5 has unfixed Remote code execution bugs so this really
doesn't matter.

On 17 July 2014 20:14, Markus Unterwaditzer notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I'm for allowing lists. Maybe we could mostly eliminate the security
> concerns by disallowing lists based on UA sniffing. It'd cause errors in
> production, but at least no security issues.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/issues/673#issuecomment-49350917.

## 

For contact info visit: www.danielchatfield.com

To clarify, i was not supporting the idea of UA sniffing, only suggesting it as a possible part of a compromise.

@danielchatfield i agree that IE5 is broken anyway, there are other browsers affected by this particular issue though.
All affected browsers are equally as old/insignificant/broken.

issues.title: Add .env support, take 2
issues.body:
Setting the `FLASK_APP` and `FLASK_DEBUG` for every new terminal session is inconvenient. The CLI could load a `.env` file that contained these values instead. Since Heroku is a popular deployment option, this would also help developers who want the same scheme locally.

Instead of writing our own parser, we should use [python-dotenv](https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv). This reduces maintenance burden on us and can be an optional dependency. If it is installed, the CLI will load the `.env`, otherwise it will skip it.

Previously discussed in #2164.

---

@miguelgrinberg raised a good point in the previous thread. `.env` is typically used to store sensitive configuration. The convenience of setting `FLASK_APP=` there could encourage users to commit the file publicly, which would be bad.

A solution would be to load two files, `.flask-env` and `.env`, and prominently document that `.flask-env` can be committed but should not contain secrets.

comments_data.body: i'd prefer `.flaskenv` similar to `.foorc` (and not `.foo-rc`)
That makes sense, I have no strong opinion on the name.

I'm in favor of using python-dotenv. I have started using it on my projects, in place of my own less robust implementation. I'm also in favor of having Flask import a `.env` file, that is not supposed to be in source control. I think this would be a great addition regardless of the main point of this discussion.

I think using a `.flaskenv` for the Flask env vars is a better idea than what we discussed in #2164. But I keep thinking that for people that use app factory functions now need to add two files: a `wsgi.py` that calls the factory function, and then this new `.flaskenv` that points to it.

Implementing support for referencing a factory function in `FLASK_APP` is, in my opinion, not a great idea because the function might need custom arguments. So I see no way to avoid the need for a `wsgi.py` file.

On the other side, the Flask CLI is perfectly happy to look for `app` or `application` in the module referenced by `FLASK_APP` if you don't give it a specific app name. So what if we also add sensible defaults for module name? For example, if `FLASK_APP` is not defined, we look for `wsgi.py` and `flaskapp.py` and use those. So then we have the following options:

- `FLASK_APP` is not defined: look for `app` or `application` in `wsgi.py` or `flaskapp.py`.
- `FLASK_APP=module.py`: look for `app` or `application` in`module.py`
- `FLASK_APP=:myapp`: look for `myapp` in `wsgi.py` or `flaskapp.py`
- `FLASK_APP=module.py:myapp`: look for `myapp` in `module.py`

@miguelgrinberg at the PyCon sprints, @HndrkMkt merged in a set of patches that allows the `flask` command to autodetect factories and `FLASK_APP` to specify them, optionally with arguments. So no wrapper file will be required in the next version. For example, `FLASK_APP=myapp:create_app('dev') flask run`. #2297, #2319, #2326

I'm not sure about autodetecting the module, that seems a bit too magical. (Yes, I realize this is weird given the rest of the autodetection.) It would only benefit single-file apps, and devs like to choose all sorts of file names whether their app is a module or a package. They would also still use `FLASK_DEBUG`.

Anyway, that's sort of tangential to the dotenv support. We should discuss that in a separate issue.

In my opinion, `FLASK_APP` is not in the same category as `FLASK_DEBUG`. The former can be considered static and universal. Needs to be set regardless of environment (dev, prod or test). The latter is a configuration setting that only applies to specific cases. And it's a setting that you can also set via the Flask config object, or the `--debug` CLI option.

The reason I brought up the defaults for module names is that if we agree to implement them, then you have a way to not need to use `FLASK_APP`.

Regarding the factory support for `FLASK_APP`, it looks pretty good, but it does not seem to cover all the possible cases. Basically I would need to do something like this:

    FLASK_APP=app:create_app(os.getenv('FLASK_CONFIG') or 'default')

The `create_app` function is in the `app/__init__.py` module. I need to debug this, but Flask master fails to import `app` as given above, for some reason. If I move `create_app` to a top-level module then that part works, but the expression I need for the function's single argument does not seem to be accepted, the factory function gets `script_info` as this configuration argument.

@miguelgrinberg, that it fails to evaluate your argument expression is due to the fact that @davidism and I decided to limit the argument support to literals. (See https://github.com/pallets/flask/pull/2326/files#diff-61bbd5ac9238364564a7315cc6bc2156R114 for the evaluation).

I'll prepare a PR later that updates docs and tests to point out this limitation.
Entering quotes in an env var is unfortunately not straightforward. We should document that. Also, it's possible to reference a var or default.

```bash
# need nested quotes to get "string" in arg list
FLASK_APP=hello:create_app("'dev'") flask run
# can get var or default
FLASK_CONFIG="'dev'" FLASK_APP=hello:create_app(${FLASK_CONFIG:-"'default'"}) flask run
```

Although in the second one, while it works, I'd rather do it in Python instead.

```python
def create_app(config=None):
    if config is None:
        config = os.environ.get('FLASK_CONFIG', 'default')
    ...
```

```bash
# all equivalent
FLASK_APP=hello flask run
FLASK_CONFIG='dev' FLASK_APP=hello flask run
FLASK_APP=hello:create_app("'dev'") flask run
```

Also, python-dotenv says it doesn't support variable defaults yet.

Regarding quotes, looks like I did not do it above in my example, but for bash, the easiest is to enclose the whole thing in doble quotes, and only use single quotes for your literals. This is actually what I tried yesterday and failed to correctly copy here:

    FLASK_APP="app:create_app(os.getenv('FLASK_CONFIG') or 'default')"

But of course, this works in bash/zsh/etc only. I suspect you are going to have a lot more trouble to get something like this to work on Windows.

Your suggested solution of letting the shell do the env var replacement should work, but again, it is a bash only solution.

Moving this logic into the factory function, as you also suggested above, is not ideal. The default could be context based, so it is better handled by the caller. When you are running unit tests, for example, you will probably want the default configuration to be `'test'` instead of `'default'`. If you are starting a Celery worker for your app, for example, you'll probably want yet another configuration to be the default.

I would personally not go through all these troubles to define `FLASK_APP`. Adding a `wsgi.py` file (which is already covered in the docs) is way more simple, and allows you to work in Python, regardless of the OS and shell that you use. So what I'm wondering is if we can agree that having a default for module name thus making `FLASK_APP` optional makes sense or not, maybe in addition to the .flaskenv effort which you seem to prefer.

If the default changes per context, then it's not a default. Isn't that the whole point of changing the env var or the argument to the factory?

Anyway, I understand that the wrapper file can still be useful for complex situations. Recognizing `wsgi.py` as a standard wrapper name, and `app.py` to support quick demo apps, seems fine.
I've moved detecting `wsgi.py` to a separate issue, #2376. Discussion here should be about the logistics of `.env` support itself.

Thanks. I'll see if I can come up with something for #2376.

Circling back to the `.flaskenv` support. One thing that I think we need to clarify is its use for FLASK_DEBUG, which can be confusing. You obviously don't want to store `FLASK_DEBUG=1` in `.flaskenv` and then commit the file to source control. If we are going to have `.env` and `.flaskenv` with only the latter on source control, it seems to me debug settings should go on the former.

Repeating an issue that was brought up in the previous thread: if `.env` is used to store secrets and is only loaded when Flask's CLI is invoked, it might have a limited use on production environments that use a WSGI server to run the application.

On the contrary, if `.env` is loaded on app instanciation, does it deprecate instance relative configurations? It seems to me these features both solve the same problem (having different secrets on different environments). For example one could write multiple `.env` files (`.env.production`, `.env.staging`, `.env.development`), not checked in version control, and push the correct file on each environment using a configuration management tool.

Instance folders don't work on services like Heroku that place their configuration in env vars and don't have persistent storage. This helps mirror that locally for developers using those services. They still have to do extra work to convert env vars to proper config values, which we recently documented. This shouldn't replace instance folders.

I see this as a convenience during development. In production, there's probably something else like Systemd or Docker setting env vars. If a developer still wants to use a `.env` file they can use python-dotenv manually during `create_app` or in `wsgi.py`.

I am going to side with @bovarysme. If the `.env` file is going to be imported, it needs to be imported regardless of how the application is started. It's too confusing and error prone to have this work only when you run the application via the flask cli.

I agree that it is a feature designed to help development, but what if I want to do a quick test running gunicorn or uwsgi? Maybe I won't even realize that I'm running a completely different configuration.

Besides, having a unified way to import environment is nice. I don't see a reason not to do this in all cases. If you don't want to do it, don't write a .env file.
Where should it be loaded then? `Flask.__init__`? It needs to be loaded before that for the CLI, but shouldn't hurt to load it in both places.
Right, that sounds tricky. Would it make sense to do it in `flask/__init__.py`? This is the main `flask` package, not the `Flask` class.
I'm not sure if I'm comfortable with import side effects, although I can't think why it would hurt in this case.

I think loading in any sort of init should be avoided if at all reasonably possible, having  dealt with packages that do that it's an absolute nightmare, not just in testing but sometimes in just running the thing.

What value does this env file serve over a cfg file that's loaded at run time? And will this open the door to people asking for other config options - do we then debate loading from redis or consul? The answer is hopefully no, but this does set the precedent for considering those if accepted.

If this is accepted as something we want, would a new method on the config object be more appropriate? Say one that accepted an env file and how to handle it?

issues.title: config.from_pyfile crashes on Python 3 when source isn't encoded in default encoding
issues.body:

what does your config file look like? and how are you calling it within your flask app? if it is an issue, not just an implementation thing, you should be posting the minimum to reproduce the error. we need a bit more information to judge whats going on.

this is my code.
```
app\__init__.py
```

hi,
I think the issue in [config.from_pyfile](https://github.com/pallets/flask/blob/master/flask/config.py#L129), it seems implicitly use default encoding, not explicitly    assign encoding to `utf-8`.
docstring in `open()` said:
> if encoding is not specified the encoding used is platform dependent: locale.getpreferredencoding(False) is called to get the current locale encoding.

I suggest to fix it to always using `encoding="utf8"`, because in windows, the default encoding might be be cp950, gbk, or cp1252...etc.

Hi, 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23103485/

lanfon72 said is right.

@xinyvz is the issue resolved? if so, what solved it? it is not entirely clear based on what you have said. please share the solution for others that might find this thread facing similar issues. and of course, close the issue if it's done.

I modify the flask.config.from_pyfile function, add a paramter, mode='rb', Solved the problem.
I'm sorry, I didn't think of other methods.

```
    def from_pyfile(self, filename, mode='rb', silent=False):
        """Updates the values in the config from a Python file.  This function
        behaves as if the file was imported as module with the
        :meth:`from_object` function.

        :param filename: the filename of the config.  This can either be an
                         absolute filename or a filename relative to the
                         root path.
        :param silent: set to ``True`` if you want silent failure for missing
                       files.

        .. versionadded:: 0.7
           `silent` parameter.
        """
        filename = os.path.join(self.root_path, filename)
        d = types.ModuleType('config')
        d.__file__ = filename
        try:
            with open(filename, mode) as config_file:
                exec(compile(config_file.read(), filename, 'exec'), d.__dict__)
        except IOError as e:
            if silent and e.errno in (errno.ENOENT, errno.EISDIR):
                return False
            e.strerror = 'Unable to load configuration file (%s)' % e.strerror
            raise
        self.from_object(d)
        return True
```
Ok, nice. Let's close this.
Not sure if this is actually resolved.

Seems the issue here is that the config file is encoded with utf8 but the machine's default locale is gbk. Either we allow passing an encoding to `from_pyfile`, or we require the encoding to be utf8. Opening the file in binary mode is not correct.
I think always using UTF-8 would be the cleanest solution.

The encoding should be indicated at the top of the file using a comment `# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-`. I do think this issue is a Python 3 portability bug and that opening the file in binary mode is correct (as is the default in Python 2). `compile()` can deal with binary strings and apparently also can detect the encoding using that comment annotation.
So if I'm right @xinyvz shouldn't have this problem in Python 2.
If Python will handle the coding comment if the file is opened in binary mode then yeah we should just always open in binary mode.
@untitaker I have not try in python2,  but I think you are right.

issues.title: Wrong import json library
issues.body:
[This code](https://github.com/pallets/flask/blob/c5900a1adf8e868eca745225f3cf32218cdbbb23/flask/json.py#L23) is always import error.
(`simplejson` is not included in the `itsdangerous`.)
See: https://github.com/pallets/itsdangerous/blob/master/itsdangerous.py

comments_data.body: indeed, how about a quick pull request removing the unnecessary lines?

It's not explicitly included, but `itsdangerous` does do a [quick check to see if it's already installed](https://github.com/pallets/flask/blob/c5900a1adf8e868eca745225f3cf32218cdbbb23/flask/json.py#L22-L25)  and uses it if it is.

That's the problem though, `itsdangerous` will never have `simplejson`, it's aliased to `json`.  Flask should just do its own check, we're not getting anything by importing itsdangerous's or werkzeug's import.
since we want to use the same module, and depend on it anyway, it makes sense to just import with the only name it will ever use
For the record: older versions of itsdangerous had this named `simplejson` which is why this was a import that supported both.
At the very least we should bump the dependency to a version of itsdangerous that includes `json` always.
What about just copying the logic from itsdangerous?
Seems more sensible to me than relying on an import in another library. I've always found it weird to make imports part of the public API.

Personally I would prefer if we documented the json attribute in itsdangerous and make it part of the public API then import it and require a specific version of it. I do not like the idea of having different json modules for Flask and itsdangerous because it becomes confusing for a user if different ones are picked up due to the different behavior on simplejson vs json on Python 3.

The import is duplicated anyway in Werkzeug for its json support, and we can't get that one from itsdangerous.  When would there ever be a situation where itsdangerous imports one but Flask imports the other?  My vote is for just duplicating the import.
The only json import that is user facing in Werkzeug is in contrib so that's not really a concern there.
Except we're talking about moving it into main right now.  pallets/werkzeug#4

If we move Json code into main werkzeug then we need to figure out a long term solution for this problem. Getting the imports right everywhere is tricky. If we do it this way then we should add comments everywhere that clarify the import order so that if anyone ever changes it anywhere, we fix it in all libraries.

Would using something like `anyjson` make sense?

Edit: Just saw they use a different api that doesn't use `dumps`/`loads` so probably no
I don't want to go down that path. But I can see that in the future there might be a simplejson2 or something like this. Why? Because stuff like this keeps happening in the Python world :(
JFTR. The stdlib json inclusion was supposed to fix this but it turns out that the JSON module in the stdlib is inferior to the one in simplejson.
Maybe it's time to just pick one?  https://github.com/pallets/flask/issues/1602#issuecomment-154135639
I don't think that is possible. We had issues before forcing simplejson on people.
Then just go with `json`?  The tests pass for both, and there's only one line of code that does anything different between the two (dealing with slash escapes in some version of simplejson).

If we decide to figure out #1602, then users will have the option of adding simplejson back in if it's something they want.  How many people are even _aware_ that Flask will use simplejson if it's available?  It's not documented anywhere.

issues.title: Move object_hook outside loads method so class can be extend and reused
issues.body: Wanted to be able to extend the session serializer class without duplicating all the code for object hook - as with the _tag function above.

comments_data.body: There's a typo in your commit message ("opbject").

Wouldn't it be better to make it a static method of `TaggedJSONSerializer`? That way you can simply subclass it instead of having to rewrite the dumps/loads methods of that class or monkeypatch.

In the same go, it'd be nice to make those two methods static, too, and use the class itself instead of an instance of it. Those methods never access `self` anyway...
Yeah I agree. I will try and do this today.
While you're at it, maybe #1511 could be interesting to fix at the same time.
I'd move the untagging code into a method, too. It's a bit pointless to be able to override it for only one direction
I have added a fix for issue #1511 as well as making the class extendible, could someone have a look and see what you think?

Looks quite complex (don't have time to thoroughly review it right now). Also, it adds a list of valid tags at yet another place, making it harder to extend... maybe it'd be worth refactoring the whole thing to change the way the conversions are defined?

``` python
conversions = {
    't': {'check': lambda value: isinstance(value, tuple),
          'tag': lambda value: [self._tag(x) for x in value]},
          'untag': lambda value: tuple(value)},
    ...
}
```

or something similar

So I have done something along the lines of your suggestion, conversions couldn't be a dict as it needs to retain order of checks, OrderedDict wasn't in python until 2.7 so tests would fail so I have made a list.

Also some tag/untag's couldn't be lambdas so had to declare self.conversions in **init** to access self._custom_tag/untag methods

Any thoughts? Looks like more code but will be much easier to extend:

``` python
def __init__(self):
    super(TaggedJSONSerializer, self).__init__()
    self.conversions.append(...)
```
did anyone check the performance on this? compared to current methods and #2093

I did a quick performance test on the session and the proposed code is slightly slower but not by much.

The test code was:

```python
import cProfile
from datetime import datetime
import uuid

import flask
from flask.sessions import TaggedJSONSerializer


def test_session_performance():
    now = datetime.utcnow().replace(microsecond=0)
    the_uuid = uuid.uuid4()

    data = [
        (1, 2, 3),
        the_uuid,
        b'\xff',
        flask.Markup('Hello!'),
        now,
    ]

    cycles = 10000

    session = TaggedJSONSerializer()

    for d in data * cycles:
        dumped = session.dumps(d)
        session.loads(dumped)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    cProfile.run('test_session_performance()')

```

Latest flask master branch:
4.319 seconds
4.409 seconds
4.455 seconds

This branch:
4.891 seconds
4.913 seconds
4.957 seconds
Is this OK to be merged? It would be good to get this functionality in.
I'm working through the PR backlog right now, this is on the list. Would you mind enabling the "allow edits from maintainers" option in the sidebar?
No problem. Done.

Re: performance: new method is ~ 30 µs slower.

~~~
old: 70.7 µs ± 164 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10000 loops each)
new: 96.3 µs ± 678 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10000 loops each)
~~~

You'd need to handle 2,000,000 requests before you wasted 1 extra minute. There's always Flask-Session, etc. where server-side sessions are serialized with `pickle`, which is *much* faster.
Hmm, maybe this should all be moved to itsdangerous. It's not actually Flask specific.
I don't really see how it's got anything to do with itsdangerous either though
The only place it's being used is passed to itsdangerous. Eh, I could go either way, probably not worth the trouble.
Continued in #2352. Thank you for working on this @s-block!
Can you add a `closes #1370` somewhere in the commit message so it closes the related issue #1370 once it's merged?

What about checking if there's a not-None return value from that signal? If there is exactly one, you could return that instead of rendering the original template. This would allow one to override the template rendering process if necessary. Could be useful in unit tests if all you care about is the context but don't want the actual template to be rendered for some reason.

> Can you add a closes #1370 somewhere in the commit message so it closes the related issue #1370 once it's merged?

I added it to the PR body, I hope that helps. Doesn't really matter though.

Hi, all!
Adrian, thank you for your review!

> What about checking if there's a not-None return value from that signal? If there is exactly one, you could return that instead of rendering the original template. This would allow one to override the template rendering process if necessary. Could be useful in unit tests if all you care about is the context but don't want the actual template to be rendered for some reason.

Actually it is not so clear for me. Do you want to use this feature only for unit tests? Because I think this will look a little bit strange in the code.

It would be one case. Another use-case could be adding extra functionality in a application that supports plugins.

For example, in the project I'm working on we have a plugin system where we let plugins override templates in some cases. While I'd mostly use the `before_render_template` signal to inject extra data in the context when overriding a template, I could imagine cases where it'd make more sense to completely intercept the rendering of a certain template.

> You can use the context manager to connect the signal temporarily

It seems that test env uses blinker v 1.0. This version doesn't have connected_to method. I think that the old approach in tests is quite ok.
I would merge the "fix" commits into the related commit (i.e. do an interactive git rebase, and mark those commits as "fixup").

Yes, I agree, thx!
It's done.
@ThiefMaster @alexpantyukhin What's up with this PR?

I guess the simple way of only sending the signal and not caring about the return value is the most straightforward way... the extra functionality I had initially suggested probably fits much better in a separate PR (that moves `_render` into the `Flask` class to allow overriding it if necessary).
I agree with @ThiefMaster .
Ok, then this implementation seems fine to me. If you agree @alexanderpantyukhin please add a changelog and proper docs for this signal. Thanks!
It seems that only person who has 'write access' can resolve conflicts in merge.

Thanks @alexanderpantyukhin!

merge conflicts can be resolved by [rebasing](https://help.github.com/articles/about-git-rebase/) your branch against master.
The history of that PR could have been cleaned up a bit :/ it's rather messy with all the intermediate "fix ..." commits... Anyway, too late for that now

issues.title: flask.ext Import Migration Tool #1135
issues.body: This is an early commit to get some feedback. This script supports single imports in two formats. I am concerned that the naive approach is not what you guys are looking for. I would obvious add support for multiple imports and the third case `import flask.ext.foo` => `import flask_foo`. But the solution is definitely super hacky.

comments_data.body:
> This script supports single imports in two formats. I am concerned that the naive approach is not what you guys are looking for.

Yeah... There are some forms with which this script would break:

```
from flask.ext.foo import \
    a, \
    b

from flask.ext.foo import (
    a,
    b
)
```

Parsing definetly should be delegated to some third-party library. As said in #1135, https://github.com/python-modernize/python-modernize looks great, but I am not sure if one can easily extend it with own fixers.

I looked into using lib2to3 initially but I didn't look at python-modernize. Upon inspection I think writing a custom fixer wouldn't be too bad. I'll work on this over the weekend. Thanks for the feedback.
@keyanp Just found https://github.com/Psycojoker/baron and https://github.com/Psycojoker/redbaron, maybe you'll find it useful.
@untitaker Thanks! That looks promising, I've been fiddling with writing a fixer for lib2to3, but it's pretty confusing. Hopefully this will be easier.

@untitaker So RedBaron ended up being perfect for the job, the new module supports everything mentioned in issue #1135 except it doesn't change imports in the format:

`import flask.ext.foo.[more stuff]` because I was not sure what this is supposed to turn into, maybe `import flask_foo.[more stuff]`?

it only handles:

`import flask.ext.foo` --> `import flask_foo`

And even it that case, it doesn't fix all the function calls in the source. As you mentioned before, that would be quite tricky, maybe a warning is sufficient? I also added a few tests, but RedBaron needs to be installed on Travis in order to pass. Please comment on whether the tests are structured as expected for the project.

Let me know how you want me to handle the above issue.

Regarding renaming functions, I think finding all `NameNode` instances and replacing them will succeed for most cases (although it might refactor code that doesn't need it, but I don't think we should care about that). That would probably also make it easier to handle the other import type properly.

There's an edge case that your tests don't cover yet, although I don't know if your code does:

```
from flask.ext.foo import bar as baz
```

That said, this looks _really_ nice! Apart from the inline code comments I gave, please also add a simple usage message if the user hasn't provided `sys.argv[1]`.

> 1. How do I pip install RedBaron on the Travis build so I can pass the build?

Enter it as dependency directly after `greenlet` under `deps= ...`

> What is the correct way to import the script into my tester file?

I was about to suggest that you move the tests for this script to the same directory as the script itself. py.test should pick it up automatically.
Great! Thanks!

So I moved the test file, added RedBaron to the dependencies, and also added an extra test for this case (which is now covered):

```
from flask.ext.foo import (
    a,
    b
)
```

Let me know if there is anything I missed, thanks for your help @untitaker

Yeah, we still have to fix imports like these:

```
import flask.ext.foo
```

Just warning about it is unfortunately not an option. :(
Yeah no problem, could you refer to the specific case you are talking about? The case you wrote in the last comment already works: import flask.ext.foo --> import flask_foo
I meant rewriting the usages of `flask.ext.foo` to the new form inside the code itself. See my comment above about NameNode.

@untitaker So I couldn't figure out a good way to do it using the NameNodes, but the function calls are represented by Atomtrailers and replacing those worked for the test files I ran it against. I added a simple test to cover that case as well. Otherwise I refactored the code a bit.
@untitaker Refactored to clean it up a bit, added the test you mentioned, and added a function to cover it. Thanks again for your help.
Looks good to me.
@untitaker What's your opinion?

In IRC I expressed the concern that this tool might rewrite things that it is not supposed to rewrite, because it doesn't do a lot of "checks" on the AST.

But since this is just a feeling I have, this is actually pretty great. Thanks @keyanp!
For future reference, followup on https://github.com/pallets/flask/issues/1765

issues.title: New label 'good first bug'
issues.body:
Sorry in advance if it is not the right place to open this kind of issue.
I think it would be nice to have issues labelled 'good first bug' for people wanting to contribute but not knowing how to start.

comments_data.body:
I am definetly open to that idea. In [Werkzeug](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/werkzeug) we do have a "beginner friendly" label, and i did use it, but since i already am too familiar with the codebase, i really don't know which bugs actually do qualify as a "good first bug".

I think @pbu88 asked a similar question, and i gave a similarly unsatisfactory answer, because i hardly know how to help here.
And of course documentation fixes are usually a good way to get started.
But at the same time probably the least fun way to contribute (is there any developer who doesn't dislike/hate writing docs, at least when it's beyond the scope of docstrings?)

Documentation fixes don't necessarily mean rewriting, typo fixes also count. Otherwise one usually gets a clearer understanding of the internals when writing documentation. I think @Ceasar's #1153 is a good example of this.
And yes, writing documentation isn't fun in neither case, but it's even less fun if you already (think you) know how everything works.

I think a good way of doing it is also having issues not necessarily easy to tackle, but labelled 'beginner friendly' as it could imply mentoring. Having someone experimented with the codebase closely helping a new contributor. This is how Mozilla does it afaik. Of course, it also depends how much contribution you would like for your projects.
I need to look how Mozilla does it. I am definetly open to mentoring, not sure why we would need a label for it though. Maybe a registry of available mentors?
The way they do it is to have a mentor assigned to an issue. The label is more to be able to find easily a bug/issue to tackle when you start contributing. It could just be a 'mentored issue' label.

:+1: Really support this. 

Maybe, also it would help something like a road map, to know where Flask is going, what is being develop, experiments being done, feature branches or something like that. Of course this may not be the best way to get you started but in my opinion, it gives the users (interested in collaborating) an idea of how they could help, or where to look at.

+1 Really support this.

On 3 November 2014 09:09, Paulo Bu notifications@github.com wrote:

> +1 Really support this.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/issues/1233#issuecomment-61448710.

So, any action items? I would be happy to start contributing. 
One first step would be to add a new label to some of those issues https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/issues as it is really hard to know what is easy what is not. And maybe assigning a mentor aswell.

@jrm2k6 This confuses me... earlier you said that beginner friendly issues don't need to be easy, but they should have a mentor assigned to them.

Some thoughts:
- It's really hard to determine the hardness of an issue without actually doing any research. This is why most of the work is intensive discussion and reading of RFCs (mostly in Werkzeug) or coming up with sensible (or rather, foolproof) APIs (mostly in Flask).
- Mentoring is extremely time-consuming for both sides, but introducing such a formal process implies to me that there is somebody working full-time on Flask/Werkzeug, so i don't think mentoring is applicable in Flask's case, while it probably is in Mozilla's.
- If you are interested in fixing an issue, i'd suggest to comment on it to see whether anybody else is currently doing anything related, otherwise you may ask where to start. I can't really see how in Flask's case, a mentoring process would give you quicker response times than this strategy.
- One bug that doesn't require deep knowledge of Flask's or Werkzeug's internals, but still is a lot of work would be https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/issues/1135 -- there we'd have to write a tool that automatically fixes the codebase of a Flask user, given that `flask.ext` is going to be deprecated.
- Anything with the 1.0 milestone (and as mentioned, any doc issues) are worthwhile fixing in the near future.

OK sorry for the confusion.
I see that #1135 is labelled 'good first bug'. 
You are right, comparing with Mozilla might have been too much. 

I will try to check #1135 if I have time. Is there any documentation about how to start? or you just clone the flask repo and make your way from there?

Flask doesn't provide any documentation on how to set up a development environment for it, mostly because there is nothing in that setup substantially different from other Python projects.

Yes, you can just clone the repo. You will also need a virtualenv for Flask's dependencies, or just use `tox` to run the testsuite locally.
@jrm2k6 Are you still interested in this?

Hi,
Sorry, kinda busy at the moment and didn't have time to commit to it. Better assign it to someone else.

I also support this. One type of issue that would be useful to tag with this label is known bugs that have a clear fix - I often see issues that are proposing slight changes to the API (whether that is error handling, restructuring responses, etc.) and as a newcomer those are particularly hard to tackle because you don't know if the changes are even wanted in the first place.

Mentors would be nice as well but I'm not sure that you guys have the time/resources to spare to make that happen.
Basically everything with a milestone is planned, if that's what you're looking for.

Would be nice if some of the core contributors could tag some more issues. I'm trying to find a new issue to work on but the tracker is not well maintained. For some of the issues it is unclear whether anyone wants work to be done (#1317, #1304, #1257) and many others are just duplicates (#1251, #1356, #1333). Willing to work on something, get in touch.

@keyanp Regarding the duplicates of https://github.com/pocoo/metaflask/issues/7, I leave them open because as soon as I close them, somebody else opens a new issue. Having a few open issues hopefully makes it clear to reporters that their bug is already known.

I'll leave comments on the other issues.

issues.title: Add http headers security notes
issues.body:
Add notes about the following http headers and protocols:

 
- SSL/HTTPS
- Security Headers
- Content Security Policy (CSP)
- HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS)
- X-FRAME-OPTIONS (Clickjacking protection)
- X-Content-Type-Options
- Cookie options
- HTTP Public Key Pinning (HPKP)

comments_data.body: Thanks @jeffwidman I did some changes and tomorrow we review the changes

I'd like to see a *strong* recommendation for people to set all these security headers on the webserver (or, if present, loadbalancer) level. Most of them don't really belong into the app itself (except maybe X-Frame-Options when framing should be allowed in some case and CORS headers since setting these globally is rarely a good idea if you aren't doing an API)

flask-secure-headers looks rather inactive (last commit 2015) and uses very poor coding practices (`from headers import *` - not only a wildcard import but also an implicit relative import that would most likely not work in PYthon 3) so I'd not even mention it.

I'd focus on mentioning a single extension (flask-talisman looks quite good and, according to their repo's org name, seems to be developed by google) and not repeat the link to them but mention that this extension can handle all these headers if someone prefers to do it on the application level.
Did some peer review with @doobeh in terms of wording concepts ->  https://github.com/pallets/flask/pull/2309/commits/09a0d2ebd1c832977b46be6d0cbd7b42944ffc49
No need to paste a bit.ly link as it's confusing... just paste the github link to the commit, and github will shorten it automatically.

@kennethreitz 
Here are the changes you requested  -> https://github.com/pallets/flask/pull/2309/commits/fcfd03146011dbb2ab77868b2f56374d51b39d56
thanks!

update docs about fallback order

commit.message:
secret key rotation: fix key list ordering

The `itsdangerous` serializer interface[1] expects keys to be
provided with the oldest key at index zero and the active signing key
at the end of the list.

We document[2] that `SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS` should be configured with
the most recent first (at index zero), so to achieve the expected
behaviour, those should be inserted in reverse-order at the head of
the list.

[1] - https://itsdangerous.palletsprojects.com/en/stable/serializer/#itsdangerous.serializer.Serializer

[2] - https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/stable/config/#SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS

verification.payload:
tree d5e116ce03842c0eeecb30624df7933314e98ffe
parent 08c480b3b31e896698bb773069026a61eb53d158
parent da600394865c06a4772c433c1a560453dcf4f868
author David Lord <davidism@gmail.com> 1743286504 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1743286504 -0700

Handle help arg by itself the same as no args (#5674)

commit.message:
Handle help arg by itself the same as no args

When the 'flask' command is used with only the '--help' parameter, this
change will make sure to try and load the app before the help callback
is run. This was previously only being done when the 'flask' command was
used by itself. This meant when passing in '--help', any custom commands
were not getting shown in the help message. With this change, custom
commands will be included in the help message when running 'flask' on
the command line by itself or with the '--help' parameter.

committer David Lord <davidism@gmail.com> 1743286403 -0700

When the 'flask' command is used with only the '--help' parameter, this
change will make sure to try and load the app before the help callback
is run. This was previously only being done when the 'flask' command was
used by itself. This meant when passing in '--help', any custom commands
were not getting shown in the help message. With this change, custom
commands will be included in the help message when running 'flask' on
the command line by itself or with the '--help' parameter.
